g.text: SHAP Analysis: Climate-Health Model Interpretability and Performance
5-Fold CV with Random Forest and XGBoost
SHAP Feature Importance: Fasting Glucose Model
Temperature lag effects (7-14 days) more predictive than
immediate climate exposure for metabolic health outcomes
• Cardiovascular outcomes (BP): Very limited climate predictability
• Metabolic markers: Moderate success with glucose prediction
• Complex multi-factorial health determinants beyond climate
• 7-14 day temperature lags most predictive for glucose
• Heat index composites outperform individual variables
• Non-linear relationships revealed by SHAP dependency plots
• Socioeconomic and genetic factors dominate climate effects
• SHAP values provide individual prediction explanations
• Glucose model R² = 0.289 suggests moderate utility
• Temperature lag effects could inform seasonal care
• Population-level patterns more reliable than individual
import shap, xgboost as xgb, sklearn.ensemble
• Feature scaling: StandardScaler for climate variables
Honest Performance Assessment Across All Biomarkers
Very poor - No meaningful climate prediction
1. Climate variables show strongest predictive power for metabolic markers
2. Cardiovascular outcomes have minimal direct climate associations
3. Temporal lag effects (7-14 days) more important than immediate exposure
4. Demographic factors remain dominant predictors across all outcomes
5. SHAP analysis reveals non-linear climate-health interactions
6. Population-level patterns more reliable than individual predictions
7. Results emphasize multi-factorial nature of health determinants
ENBEL Climate-Health SHAP Analysis | Real Performance Data | Python: shap, xgboost, sklearn | 5-fold Cross-Validation
